item.title: Australian Senator Suspended for Burqa-Wearing Stunt in Parliament
item.description: Pauline Hanson, the head of the far-right One Nation party, wore the garment as a prop to push legislation to bar the garment in public places.

item.title: As Trump Pushes to End Ukraine War, Europe Toils to Have a Say
item.description: Initially cut out of development of the 28-point peace plan, European leaders are now trying to recast its pro-Russia slant. So far, it seems to be working.

item.title: Auto Industry Was Warned For Years of Poisoning, Sickness From Car Batteries
item.description: Despite decades of evidence on the toxic effects of lead battery recycling, companies opted not to act and blocked efforts to clean up the industry.

item.title: U.S. Plans Compounds to House Palestinians in Israeli-Held Half of Gaza
item.description: The project could offer relief for tens of thousands of Palestinians who have endured two years of war, but has raised questions about whether it could entrench the partition of Gaza into Israeli- and Hamas-controlled zones.

item.title: Tariffs and Strike Drive ‘Once-in-a-Lifetime’ Boost for Canadian Wine
item.description: The trade war with the United States, bans on U.S. wine and liquor imports and a recent distributor strike in British Columbia have Canadians giving their homegrown wines another look.

item.title: Mapping the Brain’s Sense of What Goes On Inside the Body
item.description: Scientists are learning how the brain knows what’s happening throughout the body, and how that process might go awry in some psychiatric disorders.

item.title: Recycling Lead for U.S. Car Batteries Is Poisoning People
item.description: Recycling lead for U.S. car batteries is poisoning children — and we know because we tested them. Will Fitzgibbon, a reporter at The Examination, describes how children in Nigeria developed lead levels associated with lifelong brain damage, and how factory workers told us they were coughing up black dust.

item.title: Thomas King, Award-Winning Canadian Author, Says He Is Not Indigenous
item.description: Thomas King said he felt “ripped in half” on learning he had no Indigenous ancestry. The Canadian author has dedicated his career to writing about Indigenous people.

item.title: Boeing Tackles Quality With a ‘War on Defects’
item.description: Two years after a panel flew off a 737 Max, Boeing is doing more inspections, completing work in its intended order and making other changes. Can the company keep it up?

item.title: Russia Bombards Kyiv After Peace Talks End in Geneva
item.description: A missile-and-drone barrage killed at least six people in Ukraine’s capital, officials said, hours after officials said they had made some headway on a peace proposal.

item.title: BBC Chair Tries to Calm Political ‘Firestorm’ Over Trump Edit
item.description: Samir Shah defended Britain’s public broadcaster at a parliamentary committee hearing on Monday, while apologizing (again) for the misleading edit of a Jan. 6 speech by President Trump.

item.title: Warmed by Japan’s Support, Taiwan Takes Up Sushi Diplomacy
item.description: China closed off Japanese seafood imports after Japan’s new leader declared strong support for Taiwan. Suddenly, sushi is everywhere on Taiwanese social media.

item.title: Xi Presses Trump on Taiwan as They Agree to Meet in China in April
item.description: In an unusual move, Xi Jinping, the leader of China, called President Trump. The two spoke about trade, Taiwan and Ukraine, according to separate official statements.

item.title: How the Peace Plan Looks to Ukraine and Russia
item.description: Our correspondents discuss the prospects for President Trump’s plan to end the war.

item.title: Who Chanel and Louis Vuitton Have Called When Making Woven Leather Bags
item.description: As Craig Wright has built his brand, Dragon Diffusion, he has quietly built a reputation as a leather craftsman for Hermès, Chanel and others. Now he’s ready to talk about it.

item.title: Images From Vietnam’s Year of Deadly Wet Weather
item.description: Scientists suggested that climate change could make central Vietnam a global hot spot for destructive storms. This year has seemed to prove the point.

item.title: ‘Find a Job,’ Ontario Premier Tells Protester While Passing a New Housing Law
item.description: During a raucous hearing, the Ontario legislature passed a bill backed by Premier Doug Ford meant to expedite housing development and the eviction of tenants who are behind on their rent.

item.title: As Ukraine Sets ‘Red Lines,’ a U.S. Peace Plan Is Slimmed Down
item.description: Washington and Kyiv said that “highly productive” discussions over a proposal to end the war between Russia and Ukraine would continue.

item.title: Cannon and Other Artifacts Are Recovered From San José Shipwreck
item.description: Colombian scientists also retrieved three coins and a porcelain cup from the San José, which treasure hunters have come to call the Holy Grail of shipwrecks.

item.title: Gaza Humanitarian Foundation Is Closing
item.description: The Gaza Humanitarian Foundation said it had succeeded in delivering million of meals in the war-torn enclave, but some Palestinians were killed trying to obtain them.

item.title: Russian Disinformation Comes to Mexico, Seeking to Rupture US Ties
item.description: A U.S. government cable said that Kremlin-run outlets had scaled up their efforts across Latin America, seeking to turn people against the United States and garner support for Russia.

item.title: Army Chief Says France Must ‘Accept Losing Our Children,’ Igniting Uproar
item.description: The furor erupted as President Emmanuel Macron is expected to present a plan for paid, voluntary military service to bolster the armed forces against the threat from Russia.

item.title: Amid GPS and Ride-Hailing, the Allure of London’s Black Cab Endures
item.description: In a world of GPS and car-hailing apps, some Londoners still want to drive a traditional black cab. First, they must memorize thousands of city streets.

item.title: Dharmendra, Bollywood Leading Man, Dies at 89
item.description: In a career spanning nearly seven decades and more than 300 productions, he became widely popular, and wealthy, playing heroes and thieves.

item.title: Grisly Killings of a Married Couple Spark New Sectarian Unrest in Syria
item.description: The government acted quickly to tamp down reprisals in the central city of Homs as it tries to manage repeated waves of bloodshed involving minority groups.

item.title: New Studies of Dog DNA Shed Light on Pets and People
item.description: New studies of canine genetics shed light on the diversity of dogs and our longstanding, still-evolving relationship to them.

item.title: In Russian-Occupied Mariupol, Everything Ukrainian Must Go
item.description: Russia is remaking Mariupol, which was devastated by a brutal siege in 2022. Ukrainians seeking to move back are finding it hard to recognize the city, or to reclaim their property.

item.title: How a Sabotaged Ankle Monitor Ended Bolsonaro’s House Arrest
item.description: Shortly before he was expected to start serving a 27-year sentence, Brazil’s former president took a soldering iron to his tracking device.

item.title: Roya Mahboob Seeks New Ways to Educate Afghan Girls Under Taliban Rule
item.description: The entrepreneur Roya Mahboob is building off-line apps, underground networks and a global robotics team to educate Afghan girls unable to attend school.

item.title: Namibia’s New Minister of Health and Social Services Reimagines Health Care
item.description: Dr. Esperance Luvindao, who leads the country’s health and social services and is the youngest health minister in Africa, has ambitious plans.

item.title: In Michigan’s Upper Peninsula, Locals Fight for ‘The Right to Night’
item.description: Industrialization in Michigan’s Upper Peninsula has some residents pushing for protection of the region’s celestial splendor.

item.title: Putin’s Win-Win: Take a Russia-Friendly Peace Deal, or Fight On
item.description: The Kremlin’s leader is standing back as Ukraine and Europe scramble to negotiate changes to a U.S. proposal to end the war.

item.title: Skye Gyngell, Chef Who Championed ‘Slow Food,’ Dies at 62
item.description: The Australian pioneer of sustainable cooking practices that preserved local traditions died in London. She had been diagnosed with aggressive skin cancer last year.

item.title: Bolsonaro’s Arrest Exposes Limits to Trump’s Power
item.description: President Trump tried to keep the former Brazilian president, Jair Bolsonaro, out of prison. He failed, and now he is moving on.

item.title: The Danish Model for Immigration Crackdown
item.description: For European governments, Denmark’s hard-line immigration policy is a model for how to get a grip on contentious issue and stay in power. Our reporter Jeanna Smialek reports from Copenhagen on the the effects of the policy.

item.title: Democracy Is in Trouble. This Region Is Turning to Its People.
item.description: A small corner of Belgium is recruiting ordinary citizens to help create policies. Participants say it’s renewed their faith in government.

item.title: A Socialist Priest Embraces Venezuela’s Maduro, an Autocratic Leader
item.description: The Rev. Numa Molina, a Jesuit priest, has championed the poor for decades. Now, he is a power broker and a confidant of Venezuela’s embattled president, Nicolás Maduro.

item.title: Malaysia to Ban Children Under 16 From Social Media, Echoing Australia
item.description: The announcement on Sunday, which was light on details, came weeks before a similar action takes effect in Australia.

item.title: Before Berlin’s Cowboys Are Booted Off Their Land, One Final Hoedown
item.description: The town looks straight out of the Wild West, with saloons, sheriffs and cowboy hats galore, but in this endangered patch of the American frontier, everyone is speaking German.

item.title: Why a Man With U.S. Ties Fought for Russia in Ukraine
item.description: Col. Andrei Demurenko’s war story began at Fort Leavenworth, Kan., at a moment of hope and peace. It ended with a mortar blast in Ukraine.

item.title: Ukraine, U.S. Meet About Trump’s Peace Plan to End War With Russia
item.description: President Trump lashed out at Ukraine even as the talks on his peace proposal were still taking place, accusing the country’s leadership of being ungrateful for American support.

item.title: Denmark’s Migration Model
item.description: The country is getting attention for its tough asylum policies. Can they serve as a bulwark against the far right?

item.title: Israel Military Commanders Punished Over Hamas Attack Mistakes
item.description: About a dozen people were told they face dismissal or discipline for mistakes tied to the deadly Hamas-led attack that set off the war in Gaza.

item.title: Can the World Move On Without the U.S.? G20 Leaders Gave It a Shot.
item.description: With the United States boycotting the summit, other nations sought to strike new deals, and some took a tougher tone with President Trump.

item.title: Israel Says It Assassinated Top Hezbollah Commander in Lebanon
item.description: Escalating its attacks on the Iran-backed militant group in Lebanon, Israel killed Hezbollah’s military chief of staff in an airstrike on an apartment building.

item.title: Denmark Offers Lessons as Europe Toughens Up on Immigration
item.description: Like other European leaders, British Labour politicians are borrowing from Denmark’s restrictive asylum policy. One of its architects cautions that “balance” is necessary.

item.title: Haitians Rejoice Over Their First World Cup Berth in 50 Years
item.description: The national team’s success in landing a World Cup slot gave Haitians around the world a momentary reprieve from their country’s deep crises.

item.title: Fire Threatens Iran’s Ancient Forest, a World Heritage Site
item.description: Iran has been battling its worst drought in more than six decades. A blaze in the north has now eaten through parts of the old treasure.

item.title: Motorcyclist Dies in ‘Globe of Death’ Circus Accident in Italy
item.description: Christián Quezada Vasquez died after losing control during a stunt in which motorcyclists ride around a spherical cage, the circus company said.

item.title: Zelensky Is Under Pressure from Trump and Domestically
item.description: Over nearly four years of wartime leadership, analysts say the Ukrainian leader has repeatedly played weak hands wisely. A U.S. peace plan may be his biggest test.

item.title: Titanic Passenger’s Pocket Watch Sells for $2.3 Million
item.description: The watch belonged to Isidor Straus, a co-owner of Macy’s who was traveling first class on the Titanic with his wife when it sank in April 1912.

item.title: Texas Men Plotted Coup of Haitian Island to Enslave Women and Children, U.S. Says
item.description: The men, who planned to recruit homeless people for the invasion, took Haitian Creole classes and one enrolled in the U.S. Air Force to prepare for an attack by sailboat, prosecutors said.

item.title: G20 Leaders Push Back on Trump’s Ukraine Peace Plan
item.description: In a joint statement, the leaders reaffirmed their commitment to Ukraine, which faces the prospect of losing American support if it rejects the latest proposal.

item.title: After Russian Strike on Apartment Buildings, Ukraine’s Hope for Survivors Fades
item.description: Russian missiles hit apartment buildings in Ternopil this week, far from the war’s front line. Dozens of civilians, including children, were killed.

item.title: 20 Killed in Israeli Strikes as Israel and Hamas Trade Blame Over Truce
item.description: Violence has repeatedly flared up in the weeks since a cease-fire was reached, killing hundreds of Palestinians and at least three Israeli soldiers.

item.title: Pushing Off
item.description: Thanksgiving’s this coming week. How can we keep a busy holiday season from overwhelming us?

item.title: Jair Bolsonaro Arrested in Brazil Amid Fears He Might Flee to Avoid Prison
item.description: The arrest came days before the former president was expected to be ordered to begin a 27-year prison sentence for staging a failed coup.

item.title: Are Fighter Jets Canada’s ‘Bargaining Chip’ in Trade Talks?
item.description: Canada began a review of its fighter jet deal with the United States after President Trump imposed tariffs. Now, Sweden is back with a sales pitch for its own jets.

item.title: The Aftermath of a Deadly Strike in Western Ukraine
item.description: At the site of an apartment building in western Ukraine where a Russian strike killed dozens of people, the New York Times reporter Kim Barker heard reactions to a 28-point U.S. proposal to end the war.
